items.title: Mangiare più sostenibile senza cambiare completamente dieta
items.description: Mangiare in modo più sostenibile non significa stravolgere le proprie abitudini, ma iniziare a fare piccole scelte più consapevoli che si inseriscono
items.body:
Benessere Sostenibilità

Mangiare più sostenibile senza cambiare completamente dieta

Silvia Dalia

-

10 Febbraio 2026

Come mangiare sostenibile senza modificare le abitudini - Greenstyle.it

Mangiare in modo più sostenibile non significa stravolgere le proprie abitudini, ma iniziare a fare piccole scelte più consapevoli che si inseriscono davvero nella vita di tutti i giorni.
L’idea di mangiare in modo più sostenibile affascina molti, ma spaventa quasi tutti. Perché viene spesso raccontata come una rivoluzione totale, una rinuncia, una lista di cose da eliminare. In realtà, per la maggior parte delle persone, il cambiamento non passa da un taglio netto, ma da piccoli spostamenti quotidiani. Silenziosi. Molto più realistici.

Il vero cambiamento è nelle abitudini, non nel piatto
La sostenibilità a tavola non si gioca solo sugli alimenti “giusti” o “sbagliati”, ma su come mangiamo e con quale frequenza. Mangiare carne ogni tanto non è la stessa cosa che farlo ogni giorno senza pensarci. Comprare prodotti pronti per stanchezza è diverso dal farlo per automatismo. Il punto non è la perfezione, ma la ripetizione.
Molti iniziano senza stravolgere nulla. Continuano a mangiare più o meno le stesse cose, ma con un’attenzione diversa. Ridurre gli sprechi è spesso il primo passo concreto. Si cucina con quello che c’è, si smette di buttare cibo per distrazione, si impara a guardare gli avanzi come risorsa e non come scarto. Non è una scelta ideologica, è una forma di buon senso che arriva quasi da sola.Leggi ancheBonus, c’è tempo fino al 31 ottobre per risparmiare (ma non tutti lo sanno): controlla la listaQuanto guadagno con 5.000 euro sul mio libretto postale
Anche la spesa cambia, ma senza grandi dichiarazioni. Si scelgono prodotti meno confezionati quando è possibile, si guarda la provenienza con un minimo di curiosità, si accetta che non tutto deve essere disponibile sempre. Non è una rinuncia eroica, è un adattamento graduale che si inserisce nella vita reale.
Piccoli spostamenti che incidono più di quanto sembri
Mangiare più sostenibile spesso significa mangiare un po’ meno “a caso” e un po’ più con attenzione. Non nel senso delle quantità, ma delle scelte. Meno acquisti inutili, meno cibo comprato “nel dubbio”, porzioni più equilibrate che non nascono da regole rigide ma dall’ascolto.
Dieta sana e sostenibilità – Greenstyle.it
Anche il tema delle proteine animali rientra in questa logica. Non serve eliminarle per forza. Per molte persone basta toglierle dal centro fisso del piatto, smettere di considerarle automatiche. Verdure che contano davvero, legumi che non sono più l’alternativa triste, cereali che tornano a essere parte del pasto quotidiano. Non per moda, ma perché funzionano.
C’è poi la questione del tempo. Mangiare in modo più sostenibile richiede un minimo di organizzazione, ma non una vita dedicata ai fornelli. A volte basta cucinare una volta in più a settimana, pensare due pasti invece di improvvisare sempre. Meno stress, meno sprechi, meno decisioni dell’ultimo minuto.
Le contraddizioni fanno parte del percorso. Un giorno si fa attenzione, il giorno dopo no. Succede. Non annulla tutto, non rende inutile ciò che si è fatto prima. La sostenibilità reale non è lineare, è fatta di compromessi e aggiustamenti continui.
Mangiare più sostenibile senza cambiare completamente dieta significa rendere il cambiamento compatibile con il lavoro, la famiglia, la stanchezza. Significa smettere di vivere il cibo come un campo di battaglia morale e iniziare a vederlo come uno spazio di scelte imperfette, ma migliori di prima. Non resta una nuova dieta, ma un modo diverso di stare a tavola. Più attento, meno automatico. E spesso, proprio per questo, anche più piacevole.

Mangiare in modo più sostenibile non significa stravolgere le proprie abitudini, ma iniziare a fare piccole scelte più consapevoli che si inseriscono davvero nella vita di tutti i giorni.

items.title: Nature Restoration Law: bene il recepimento, ora servono i finanziamenti
items.description:
WWF Italia e Lipu accolgono con favore l'iniziativa del Governo di recepire il Regolamento europeo sul ripristino della natura
The post Nature Restora
items.body: In evidenza WWF Italia: 60 anni per la natura In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza L'orso bruno marsicano In evidenza Adotta una specie WWF Italia e Lipu accolgono con favore l’iniziativa del Governo di recepire il Regolamento europeo sul ripristino della natura (Nature Restoration Law) attraverso il decreto legislativo all’esame del Parlamento. Le due organizzazioni, tuttavia, esprimono preoccupazione per l’assenza di risorse finanziarie specificamente destinate all’attuazione concreta degli obiettivi di ripristino: senza finanziamenti adeguati, l’Italia rischia di non rispettare gli impegni assunti in sede europea entro il 2030. Le associazioni hanno espresso la loro posizione oggi nel corso dell’audizione parlamentare alla Commissione Ambiente del Senato sul decreto legislativo per il recepimento della Nature Restoration Law. Le risorse per la natura sono un investimento nel futuro del Paese: gli ecosistemi sani sono alla base dei servizi essenziali per la vita umana – acqua pulita, aria respirabile, suoli fertili, protezione dalle alluvioni – Ogni anno di ritardo aumenta il costo del ripristino e riduce le possibilità di successo. Un Regolamento storico che impone obiettivi concreti Il Regolamento (UE) 2024/1991 rappresenta il primo strumento giuridicamente vincolante che garantisce obiettivi concreti e misurabili per il recupero degli ecosistemi degradati e dei relativi servizi ecosistemici: una norma di portata storica per la tutela della biodiversità europea, che l’Italia è chiamata a recepire con la massima serietà e con gli strumenti operativi adeguati. “Il Piano Nazionale di Ripristino, principale strumento attuativo del Regolamento, dovrà tradursi in interventi concreti su ecosistemi terrestri, marini, fluviali, forestali e agricoli in tutto il territorio nazionale – affermano WWF Italia e Lipu – Interventi che richiedono risorse finanziarie certe, programmate e dedicate”. Il nodo finanziario: il rischio dell’invarianza Lo schema di decreto legislativo in esame, come osservato nel corso dell’audizione parlamentare alla Commissione Ambiente del Senato, si limita a disciplinare la governance del Regolamento e, all’articolo 6, stabilisce l’invarianza finanziaria. Se questa scelta può ritenersi giustificabile per le disposizioni strettamente organizzative, essa diventa però inaccettabile se verrà estesa all’attuazione del Piano Nazionale di Ripristino. “In assenza di adeguate risorse finanziarie specificatamente destinate all’attuazione del Piano Nazionale di Ripristino, risulterà impossibile rispettare gli impegni e conseguire gli obiettivi previsti dal Regolamento europeo” – aggiungono WWF Italia e Lipu. Il 2030 è vicino: cosa chiedono WWF e Lipu Con meno di cinque anni al 2030 – prima grande scadenza degli obiettivi europei di ripristino – non vi è tempo da perdere. Le due organizzazioni chiedono l’integrazione del decreto legislativo con disposizioni che: Obblighino le amministrazioni pubbliche competenti a destinare, nella programmazione annuale e pluriennale, risorse finanziarie specifiche all’attuazione del Piano Nazionale di Ripristino, attingendo ai fondi dell’Unione europea, nazionali e regionali disponibili. Prevedano meccanismi di incentivazione fiscale – in primo luogo crediti d’imposta – per imprese e soggetti privati che intendano contribuire finanziariamente all’attuazione del Piano. Garantiscano un coordinamento efficace tra tutti i livelli istituzionali coinvolti – Ministeri, Regioni, Province autonome, enti gestori di aree protette e siti Natura 2000 – per evitare dispersione e sovrapposizione di risorse. Rafforzino la governance del Regolamento, ampliando la composizione del Tavolo di indirizzo e coordinamento strategico (art. 5) per includervi rappresentanti delle Regioni, delle autorità di bacino distrettuali, degli enti gestori delle aree naturali protette – sia pubblici sia privati – e un rappresentante del Ministero dell’Economia e delle Finanze, il cui coinvolgimento è imprescindibile proprio per garantire l’adeguata dotazione finanziaria del Piano. 4 Aprile 2025 Aree protette: il WWF a Castelporziano delinea una roadmap per l’Italia per raggiungere gli obiettivi 2030 I risultati del convegno nazionale organizzato da WWF Italia presso la Tenuta presidenziale di Castelporziano dal 2 al 4 aprile 4 Dicembre 2025 Consumo suolo, WWF: serve un cambio di rotta immediato Per il WWF è urgente approvare una legge quadro sul consumo del suolo e dare attuazione alla Direttiva Europea 2360 6 Luglio 2023 Il Manifesto per la Nature Restoration Law Oltre 150 associazioni insieme a centinaia di ricercatori e personalità della scienza e della cultura chiedono di approvare la legge europea 12 Luglio 2023 Il Parlamento UE approva la legge per il ripristino della natura Respinto il tentativo di bloccare la Nature Restoration Law ma il Parlamento europeo approva una legge indeboli

items.title: Il rapporto strano che abbiamo con la plastica: perché sappiamo che è un problema ma continuiamo a usarla
items.description: Usiamo la plastica ogni giorno sapendo che è un problema, e proprio questa convivenza silenziosa racconta molto del nostro modo di vivere e consumare.
items.body:
Ambiente Inquinamento

Il rapporto strano che abbiamo con la plastica: perché sappiamo che è un problema ma continuiamo a usarla

Silvia Dalia

-

10 Febbraio 2026

Perché usiamo sempre la plastica - Greenstyle.it

Usiamo la plastica ogni giorno sapendo che è un problema, e proprio questa convivenza silenziosa racconta molto del nostro modo di vivere e consumare.

La plastica la conosciamo fin troppo bene. Sappiamo dove finisce, quanto dura, quanto pesa sull’ambiente. Eppure la usiamo ogni giorno come se fosse neutra, inevitabile, quasi invisibile. Bottiglie, imballaggi, sacchetti, confezioni. La tocchiamo decine di volte al giorno senza pensarci davvero. Non è mancanza di informazione. È abitudine. Ed è proprio qui che il discorso diventa scomodo.
Perché continuiamo a usarla anche sapendo che è un problema
La plastica è comoda. Funziona. Costa poco, pesa poco, resiste a tutto. Protegge il cibo, semplifica il trasporto, rende veloce una vita che va già di corsa. Nella quotidianità risolve problemi immediati e concreti, ed è difficile rinunciarci quando il tempo è poco e le alternative sembrano complicate o lontane.
Il paradosso è evidente: sappiamo che è un problema globale, ma nel gesto quotidiano resta la soluzione più facile. La bottiglia d’acqua presa al volo, il sacchetto in più al supermercato, la vaschetta “per comodità”. Ogni scelta sembra piccola, quasi irrilevante. Messa insieme alle altre, però, costruisce un sistema che si autoalimenta.Leggi anche11 Dicembre | Giornata Internazionale della MontagnaDove si vive meglio in Italia? La classifica delle province più vivibili (e sostenibili) con qualche sorpresa
Plastica ed inquinamento – Greenstyle.it
Spesso il tema viene raccontato come una questione di volontà individuale, ma la realtà è più complessa. Anche chi prova a ridurre la plastica si muove dentro un contesto che la propone ovunque. Prodotti sfusi sempre più rari, imballaggi multipli, alternative sostenibili che costano di più o richiedono tempo. Vorremmo fare meglio, ma il contesto non aiuta, e questa frizione continua logora anche le migliori intenzioni.
C’è poi un altro elemento decisivo: la plastica è diventata così diffusa da non farsi più notare. È ovunque, quindi smettiamo di vederla. La usiamo, la buttiamo, la differenziamo quando va bene, e il problema sembra chiuso. Il fatto che continui a esistere per decenni fuori dal nostro sguardo rende tutto più facile da rimuovere mentalmente.
Le conseguenze reali e il senso di colpa quotidiano
Il rapporto con la plastica è fatto di tentativi e contraddizioni. Un giorno si porta la borraccia, il giorno dopo si compra una bottiglia. Si alternano buone intenzioni e stanchezza. Il rischio è trasformare tutto in una questione morale, dove ogni scelta sbagliata pesa più di quelle giuste.
Eppure il cambiamento raramente è lineare. È fatto di compromessi, di piccoli aggiustamenti, di passi avanti e indietro. Vale per chiunque, anche per chi è sensibile ai temi ambientali da anni. La plastica diventa così il simbolo di un disagio più ampio: sapere cosa sarebbe meglio fare, ma non riuscire sempre a farlo.
Il punto è che la plastica non è solo un problema lontano o teorico. Ha effetti concreti su ciò che mangiamo, sull’acqua che beviamo, sugli spazi che abitiamo. Ma soprattutto racconta qualcosa del nostro modo di vivere, di consumare, di gestire la complessità. Ridurne l’uso non significa diventare perfetti o rinunciare a tutto, significa tornare a vederla, riconoscerla nei gesti quotidiani senza finta innocenza ma anche senza sensi di colpa continui.
Forse il cambiamento non passa dal “mai più plastica”, ma dal smettere di far finta che non esista. Da lì in poi ogni scelta, anche piccola, smette di essere simbolica e diventa reale.

Usiamo la plastica ogni giorno sapendo che è un problema, e proprio questa convivenza silenziosa racconta molto del nostro modo di vivere e consumare.

La plastica la conosciamo fin troppo bene. Sappiamo dove finisce, quanto dura, quanto pesa sull’ambiente. Eppure la usiamo ogni giorno come se fosse neutra, inevitabile, quasi invisibile. Ed è proprio qui che il discorso diventa scomodo.

Il punto è che la plastica non è solo un problema lontano o teorico. Ha effetti concreti su ciò che mangiamo, sull’acqua che beviamo, sugli spazi che abitiamo. Ma soprattutto racconta qualcosa del nostro modo di vivere, di consumare, di gestire la complessità. Ridurne l’uso non significa diventare perfetti o rinunciare a tutto, significa tornare a vederla, riconoscerla nei gesti quotidiani senza finta innocenza ma anche senza sensi di colpa continui.
Forse il cambiamento non passa dal “mai più plastica”, ma dal smettere di far finta che non esista. Da lì in poi ogni scelta, anche piccola, smette di essere simbolica e diventa reale.

Mangiare più sostenibile senza cambiare completamente dieta

items.title: MORICHI: a Dataset to Study Urban Overheating during Extreme Heat in a Hot-Summer Humid Continental Climate
items.body:
Download PDF

Data Descriptor
    
        
            Open access

Published: 10 February 2026

MORICHI: a Dataset to Study Urban Overheating during Extreme Heat in a Hot-Summer Humid Continental Climate
                    Miguel Martin 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2673-68441, Clara Garcia-Sanchez 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-5355-42721, Jantien Stoter1 & …Mario Berges 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2948-92362 Show authors

Scientific Data

, Article number:  (2026)
            Cite this article
                    
                    
                    
                            We are providing an unedited version of this manuscript to give early access to its
                            findings. Before final publication, the manuscript will undergo further editing. Please note
                            there may be errors present which affect the content, and all legal disclaimers apply.

Subjects
        
            Climate-change mitigationEnvironmental health

AbstractThis paper describes a firsthand and open dataset comprising weather data collected from four street-level stations and microscale thermal images captured by a single infrared thermal camera during an extreme heat event in late August 2024 in Pittsburgh, United States. The weather data includes air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, and rainfall, measured at a height of 2 meters above the ground. From microscale thermal images, it is possible to assess the temperatures of built-up surfaces within a street canyon on a university campus, including a road, sidewalks, and building façades. Other factors that contribute to or mitigate urban overheating, such as waste heat emissions, traffic, and vegetation, can also be analyzed using the microscale thermal images. The weather data and microscale thermal images are publicly accessible in the 4TU.ResearchData repository under the CC BY 4.0 license. A Python library was developed to extract and process the data, particularly microscale thermal images, and is publicly available via the PIP package installer.

Data availability
                  
                  The MORICHI dataset is available on the 4TU.ResearchData (https://data.4tu.nl), where it can be found by searching for “MORICHI". In this repository, the MORICHI dataset consists of a sequence of compressed files containing weather data and microscale thermal images.
               Code availability
                  
                  A Python module, irim, has been developed as part of the sciencespy library to facilitate the extraction and processing of microscale thermal images in the MORICHI dataset. The sciencespy Python library is publicly available under the GNU GPL license. It can be installed using the PIP package installer as:

items.title: Reconstructing storm Gloria in a changing climate using physical storylines
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 10 February 2026

Reconstructing storm Gloria in a changing climate using physical storylines
                    Katherine Grayson1, Diego Campos1,2, Sebastian Beyer3, Amal John3, Gerrit Versteeg1, Matthias Kelbling4, Aparna Chandrasekar4, Stephan Thober4 & …Francisco J. Doblas-Reyes1,5 Show authors

npj Natural Hazards

volume 3, Article number: 14 (2026)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            AttributionClimate and Earth system modellingClimate-change impactsNatural hazards

AbstractWe present a storyline analysis investigating the impacts of background warming on storm Gloria, a severe winter storm that affected the western Mediterranean in January 2020, producing exceptional precipitation, fatalities, and substantial economic damage. The study employs global, ~ 9 km, IFS-FESOM simulations, constrained with spectral nudging to reproduce large-scale conditions under Counterfactual, Actual, and Future climates between 2017 and 2024. The plausibility of the simulated climates is assessed by comparing relative changes in seven-year DJF distributions of precipitable water (PW), integrated vapour transport (IVT) and precipitation between the Counterfactual and Actual simulations against corresponding Past and Present periods in ERA5. The close agreement indicates that the simulated thermodynamic differences are consistent with reanalysis-based differences. We then examine Gloria’s evolution across the three climates. PW and IVT increase with warming rates close to Clausius-Clapeyron scaling. In contrast, precipitation show strong spatial heterogeneity and differences deviate from thermodynamic scaling due to changes in the persistence and organisation of vertical motion. Despite local variability, total event-integrated precipitation increases by 6.3% from the Counterfactual to the Future climate. These findings illustrate the strengths and limitations of spectrally-nudged storylines for dynamically complex storms and their value in separating thermodynamic amplification from dynamical modulation.

                        IntroductionIn January 2020, the winter storm ‘Gloria’ hit the Iberian Peninsula and the Balearic Islands. From the 19th till the 24th, records set by the storm included wave heights over 8.4 m, more than 3000 lightning strikes in one day, and over 300 mm of accumulated precipitation observed at seven different observational stations, of which one in Valencia recorded 433 mm, four times the average amount for January1. Severe flash flooding subsequently occurred, compounded by the overflow of inland rivers (e.g., the Ebro river delta) induced by the extreme storm surge2. As the storm progressed, it became cut off from the main flow, converting into a cut-off low (COL) which stalled over the region, leading to more severe and prolonged impacts. Overall, the storm resulted in 14 fatalities, more than 80 people injured, and accumulated 219 million euros of financial damages3, evidencing the vulnerability of the Mediterranean coast to large-scale atmospheric disturbances2,4.It is already well established that the Iberian peninsular is strongly affected by extreme precipitation events driven by large-scale circulation patterns such as extra-tropical cyclones (ECTs)5,6 and COLs7,8. This is recently evidenced not just by storm Gloria but also by the devastating torrential rains around the Valencia region during late October 20249. Yet questions still remain as to how these types of events will evolve in the future due to anthropogenic warming. The Mediterranean has already been identified as a climate change hot-spot10, with state-of-the-art global climate models (GCMs) showing an accelerated rate of warming11 coupled with a decrease in both projected summer11 and winter12,13 precipitation. Some studies show a reduction in frequency of ETCs over the Mediterranean due to a weakening in the storm track5, while also highlighting an amplification of the storm intensity13,14 and increase in precipitation extremes15.In this context, quantifying the impacts of anthropogenic warming to the frequency and intensity of these extreme synoptic weather events is critical and several methodologies have been developed for extreme event attribution (EEA). Specifically EEA mainly focuses on two types of questions: (a) ”has anthropogenic climate change influenced the likelihood of an extreme event?” and (b) ”has anthropogenic climate change affected the severity of a given extreme event?”. The former is often addressed using extreme value statistics and using large-ensemble simulations16. However, extreme storm events remain challenging due to the large uncertainty in our understanding of how the dynamical conditions that drive these events will be modified under climate change17. Indeed, one of the unique synoptic features of storm Gloria was the intense pressure gradient driven by a high pressure blocking system. However blocking events are often under represented in climate models and there is no clear signal as to how their intensity and frequency will evolve under a changing climate18. Applying extreme value statistics to analyse the probability of a Gloria type of event occurring in the future will naturally incur large uncertainties.The physical storyline approach (hereafter referred to as storylines) has been used to primarily answer question (b). Rather than attempting to quantify how dynamical drivers of extreme events will change under warming, the storyline methodology regards the dynamics as fixed, instead focusing on how background thermodynamics of climate change would impact particular events19,20,21. The storylines technique can boost awareness and incentivize local or regional decision-making by relying on emotionally charged experiences of recent extreme events22. In this way, storylines act as a powerful tool, as societies tend to learn from these extreme events and will attach greater subjective probability to events they have personally experienced23. This deterministic approach to quantifying the role of climate change can be implemented using a variety of methods, of which spectral nudging is becoming well established in regional and global climate modelling communities. Spectral nudging constrains simulations24 to realistically represent the dynamic atmospheric conditions during a given event25. Climate models are then run under different warming scenarios with spectral nudging to study the role of anthropogenic warming on extreme events26.Storylines implemented with spectral nudging are growing in popularity. For example, the works by27,28,29 all used the spectral nudging technique to respectively study; the 2011/2012 South American summer drought, a heatwave in 2019 over Germany and cold extremes over east Asia. Indeed, spectral nudging studies often examine extreme temperature events due to their clear links with the thermodynamic characteristics of climate change. Fewer works have focused on extreme storm events, where complexity arises from the interplay between convective and mesoscale processes, orographic influences, and larger-scale dynamical drivers. In this work we use spectrally nudged climate storyline simulations to investigate the impacts of anthropogenic warming on storm Gloria, as the records it broke mark its uniqueness and require closer inspection.To implement this study we use the simulations developed by30, using the IFS-FESOM (atmosphere-ocean)31 coupled model nudged hourly with ERA532, run globally at approximately 9 km from 2017 to 2024 (see Section Model Setup). The year 2017 is treated as a spin-up year and is left out of analysis. There are three scenarios corresponding to different background climates; a Counterfactual (~ 1950s), Actual (~ 2020, representing the event as it occurred) and a Future (~ 2040) warming scenario. In addition to the single member that spans the full 8 year period, an additional four members are run for January 2020, providing a 5-member ensemble for this month for each warming scenario. These simulations were run as part of the European Union’s Destination Earth initiative, for the creation of the climate digital twin (ClimateDT)33,34.ResultsEvent characterizationFigure 1c–n depicts the development of storm Gloria in 24 h intervals from 18th January 2020 at 12:00 UTC to 23rd at 12:00 UTC. The Gloria storm started as upper-level trough over the North Atlantic on 18th (Fig. 1c, d) and by the 19th had established itself over the Iberian peninsular, centred to the east of Ibiza island. This weak surface depression was favoured by an intense mid-tropospheric trough and a blocking anticyclone over the British Isles2,35. While the low-pressure system persisted off the coast of Valencia, a strong pressure gradient developed, generating northeasterly surface winds that impacted the Mediterranean coast of Spain with wind gusts exceeding 100 km h−1 in the Province of Valencia1 (Fig. 1e, f).Fig. 1: Spatio-temporal development of precipitation, precipitable water (PW), integrated vertical transport (IVT) and mean sea level pressure (MSLP) for storm Gloria.Panels (a, c, e, g, i, k, m) show the ensemble mean of the Actual IFS-FESOM spectrally-nudged storyline simulations while panels (b, d, f, h, j, l, n) show data from ERA5 reanalysis. a, b Accumulated precipitation from 18th-23rd January 2020. Filled circles in (b) show accumulated precipitation from AEMET and Meteocat weather stations. The dashed black box in (a) defines the eastern Spain (ES) region considered in later analysis. The blue star and dot represent the approximate centres of the Catalonia and Valencia regions respectively, shown for reference. c–n IVT, PW and MSLP shown by arrows, colour and contours respectively.Full size imageOver the following days, the depression became cut-off from the main flow, becoming quasi-stationary over the Alboran Sea from 20th to 22nd (Fig. 1g–l). This enhanced the flow from the southeast, bringing warm and moist unstable air into the region, with hourly IVT magnitudes over 500 kg m−1 s−1 recorded over the Spanish Mediterranean coast (Fig. 1g–l), Figure S1a, b). This intense moisture transport, together with the complex orography of the region established a perfect situation for deep convection resulting record-breaking precipitation in northeastern Spain, particularly around the province of Catalonia (Fig. 1a, b), Figure S1c. The strong pressure gradients gradually weakened and moved northwestward on 22nd and 23rd (Fig. 1k–n), marking the end of the event. In addition to the intense winds and precipitation, the storm also induced a strong ocean response, heavily impacting coastal areas due to the storm surge. In this work we focus on the thermodynamic and dynamic atmospheric components of the storm, with details of the marine and coastal impacts available in2,35,36.Synoptic scale model validationThe temporal evolution of precipitable water (PW), integrated vapour transport (IVT), and mean sea level pressure (MSLP) over the days of the storm, along with the cumulative precipitation are used to validate the results of the Actual storyline scenario. ERA5 reanalysis32, Multi-Source Weighted-Ensemble Precipitation (MSWEP)37 and observational station data are used as the reference baselines. Although it can be expected that the comparison between the IFS-FESOM storyline simulations and ERA5 results in a close match because ERA5 has been used for the spectral nudging, it is necessary to validate that it is indeed the case.From Fig. 1, it can be inferred that the main characteristics of storm Gloria are well represented by the Actual simulation (5 member ensemble mean) compared to ERA5. For example, the rotation center located northwest of the peninsula along with the intense moisture transport from the west on January 18th (Fig. 1c, d), as well as the position of the surface low between 19th and 20th (Fig. 1e–h) are both well captured by the Actual simulation. Similarly, the position of the pressure gradient driving the direction and magnitude of the IVT impacting the Mediterranean coast between 21st and 22nd show similar structure and magnitude in the Actual simulation compared to ERA5 (Fig. 1i–l). Despite not being directly nudged in the storyline simulations, the hourly values of PW, IVT and MSLP in the Actual simulations all show statistically significant (mean p-value of 0 for MSLP and IVT, 1e−4 for PW) Pearson correlations (r > 0.8) with ERA5 during the days of storm Gloria, shown in Figure S2c, d, g, h. The Actual simulation show strong agreement with ERA5 and ground stations in terms of the spatial distribution of precipitation accumulations, shown in Fig. 1a, b. The Spearman’s rank correlations (mean p-value of 0.0082) for precipitation between the Actual simulation and ERA5, shown in Figure S2(h), are greatest and statistically significant over the eastern Peninsula, indicating good agreement for the ES region.In terms of accumulation magnitudes in Fig. 1a, b the Actual simulations, ERA5 and ground stations all show relatively good agreement, with peak values exceeding 200 mm in the coastal area of Catalonia and widespread accumulations above 100 mm across the Mediterranean coast of Spain. However, there is an underestimation in both the Actual and ERA5 accumulations compared to the ground stations for values over 250 mm, especially around the region of southern Catalonia. This underestimation of the peak magnitudes is not unexpected given the ~ 0. 1∘ and ~ 0.25∘ resolution of the Actual and ERA5 datasets, where localised peak precipitation magnitudes will be smoothed. To assess precipitation in further detail, the Taylor diagram in Figure S3 compares the evolution of the Actual simulations, ERA5 and MSWEP over the eastern Spain (ES) region (Fig 1a) against all the ground stations shown in Fig. 1b over the days of the storm. We find a correlation of approximately 0.84 between the Actual timeseries and the ground stations, while both ERA5 and MSWEP have correlations around 0.94 and 0.92 respectively. The average precipitation magnitude is generally well represented, however the Actual simulation fails to truly represent the intensity of the precipitation peaks observed around 00:00 UTC on the 22nd and 23rd January 2020 in the ground stations. While not fully captured, these peaks are better represented in the ERA5 and MSWEP datasets.Multi-year model validationTo address the central research question of how anthropogenic warming alters the intensity of storm Gloria, we need to firstly, reproduce the synoptic-scale dynamics of the event correctly and secondly, ensure that the warming scenarios used in the comparison are representative of the background climates they intend to emulate. To answer the second point, we thereforeexamine the 7-year DJF distributions (2017 excluded as a spin-up) of four key variables in the ES region: precipitable water (PW), integrated vapor transport (IVT), convective available potential energy (CAPE) and precipitation, all of which contributed to the extremeness of storm Gloria. The distributions of the Counterfactual and Actual simulations are compared with their corresponding ERA5 reference periods, 1950–1956 (hereafter Past) and 2018–2024 (hereafter Present), respectively. This comparison serves as a consistency check, validating that the background temperature differences between the Counterfactual and Actual scenarios produce physically plausible shifts in the distributions of the variables of interest. Demonstrating this consistency provides confidence that the background thermodynamic states in the simulations reflect realistic responses to warming, thereby forming a credible basis for assessing the relative impact of anthropogenic warming on storm Gloria.Figure 2b presents the cumulative distribution functions (CDFs) of daily mean IVT averaged over the ES region, fitted with Gamma distributions for each warming scenario (Table S1). Details of the CDF construction and confidence interval (CI) estimation are provided in Section Fitting of probability distributions. The vertical black dashed line denotes the maximum daily IVT averaged over the ES region during storm Gloria (21st January 2020) in the Actual scenario, while the horizontal lines indicate the corresponding cumulative probabilities in each warming scenario. The analogous ERA5-based IVT distributions are shown in Fig. 2a, where the blue and pink curves represent daily mean IVT averaged over the ES region for the Past and Present DJF seasons, respectively. Thus, the Actual (pink) curve in Fig. 2b and the Present (pink) curve in Fig. 2a represent the same background climates and synoptic-scale environments, while the blue curves (Counterfactual in Fig. 2b and Past (Fig. 2a) aim to represent the same background climates but with different dynamics.Fig. 2: Distributions of daily mean IVT and 5-day precipitation accumulation over the ES region for Past and Present periods in ERA5 and the three warming scenarios.a, b Cumulative Distribution Functions (CDFs) of the daily mean IVT values for all boreal winter (DJF) days over the ES region for (a) ERA5 and (b) IFS-FESOM storyline simulations. The blue and pink CDFs in (a) use the 1950–1956 (Past) and 2018–2024 (Present) periods respectively. The three CDFs in (b) represent the Counterfactual (blue), Actual (pink) and Future (red) warming scenarios over the 2018-2024 period. Shading represents the 95% confidence interval obtained by bootstrapping (n = 1000). c, d Probability of Exceedance (PE) of the 5-day accumulated precipitation distributions using all boreal winter (DJF) days. Each dot represents a 5-day precipitation accumulation value for an individual grid cell within the ES region. c ERA5 and (d) IFS-FESOM storyline simulations using the same temporal periods as (a, b). The black vertical dashed lines indicate (a, b) the maximum daily value of IVT averaged over the ES region during storm Gloria in the Actual scenario, (c, d) the grid cell in the ES region with the maximum 5-day accumulation value on the 23rd January 2020 in the Actual scenario.Full size imageComparing the probability of attaining the storm Gloria-level IVT between the Past and Present periods in ERA5 (Fig. 2a), we find an increase of 2.4% [95% CI: −0.4% to 4.9%]. We then compare this observed increase with that derived from the Counterfactual and Actual warming scenarios (Fig. 2b) to assess whether the modelled change in probability is consistent with reanalysis-based changes. In this case, we find an increase of 3.2% [95% CI: −0.1% to 6.6%]. Although the ERA5 Past and IFS-FESOM Counterfactual distributions represent different dynamical conditions, both correspond to cooler climates relative to the present. The similarity in the probability increases therefore suggests that the IFS-FESOM model’s response to warming is broadly consistent with the reanalysis. However, as the 95% confidence intervals (CIs) of the probability differences include zero, these increases are not statistically significant. Statistically significant increases of similar magnitude between the ERA5 Past-Present and Counterfactual-Actual scenarios are found for PW (Figure S4), whereas CAPE (Figure S5) shows a weaker and less robust increase. The increases in the probability of exceedance (PE) of the atmospheric variables observed during Gloria in the warmer scenarios are associated with the atmosphere’s enhanced capacity to retain moisture in a warmer climate, further discussed in Section Clausius-Clapeyron scaling.Figure 2c, d shows a similar analysis but this time for DJF 5-day precipitation accumulations, including every grid cell in the ES region. Due to the extremely skewed nature of precipitation distributions, no curves are fitted in Fig. 2c, d, rather the raw distributions of the 5-day accumulations are shown. 5-day accumulations are examined, as opposed to daily, due to the longevity of the storm. For both the ERA5 Present day distribution (Fig. 2c, pink) and the Actual scenario distribution (Fig. 2d, pink), the black vertical line – marking the grid cell with the maximum 5-day accumulation on 23rd – corresponds to the most extreme value in each distribution. As the corresponding precipitation magnitude is larger than any value in either the Past ERA5 or Counterfactual distributions, a comparison of the change in PE cannot be made. We do however note similar separations between the blue and pink curves in Fig. 2c, d, culminating in an approximate increase of 20 mm between the maximum values of the ERA5 Past-Present and IFS Counterfactual-Actual scenario distributions.Regarding the magnitude of the precipitation bias, Fig. 2c shows extreme precipitation magnitudes in ERA5 to be lower than those in the corresponding Actual storyline distributions (Fig. 2d), while Section Synoptic scale model validation showed that precipitation intensities during storm Gloria in the Actual simulation are underestimated relative to observations. As a result, we further compare precipitation distributions over the 7-years using a probability of exceedance (PE)-based framework, which allows the relative extremeness of storm Gloria to be assessed independently of biases in absolute magnitude. Figure S6 compares the PE of storm Gloria against DJF precipitation distributions from ERA5, MSWEP, and ground-based observations for the 2018-2024 period. The three vertical dashed lines in Figure S6a, (which does not include the ground stations) indicate the maximum 5-day accumulation obtained in the ES region for the 23rd for each dataset. While the precipitation magnitudes differ – as expected given the lower resolution of ERA5 – each dataset marks the 23rd January 2020 as the most extreme value over these 7 years. The same result is found when also considering the ground stations in Figure S6b.Overall, the relative differences between the Counterfactual and the Actual warming scenarios in the IFS-FESOM spectrally nudged simulations appear physically plausible and consistent with the real-world response to increased background temperatures. Moreover, while the magnitude of the precipitation is not matched, the relative extremeness of the event is properly represented. For obvious reasons, we can not perform the same validation for the Future warming scenario however we observe a smaller difference in the Future scenario distributions compared to the Actual - Counterfactual differences.Spatio-temporal response of atmospheric variables during storm GloriaWe now examine the response of the storm event in the three different background climates to answer the questions ‘how much of the intensity of storm Gloria can be attributed to climate change’ and ‘would the event be further modified if it were to have occurred in a warmer climate?’We first examine the response of PW between the warming scenarios in Fig. 3a–c, which shows the differences between the ensemble means of the Actual − Counterfactual (A − C), Future − Actual (F − A) and Future − Counterfactual (F − C) scenarios. All three panels in Fig. 3a–c are always positive, meaning the magnitude of the cooler scenario in each comparison never exceeds the magnitude of the warmer scenario in any part of the domain. The PW differences are also relatively spatially homogeneous; however larger differences do occur over the oceans. The magnitude of the PW difference in A − C compared to F − A is larger, despite a similar spatial structure. Figure 4a shows the ES region spatially averaged PW time-series for the five members in each warming scenario. The average ensemble mean differences between F − A (as a percentage of A) and A − C (as a percentage of C) are found to be 5.7 ± (0.4/0.5) %, 10.7 ± (1.2/0.7) % respectively.Fig. 3: Differences between PW, IVT, CAPE, time integrated mean vertical motion and accumulated precipitation between the three warming scenarios.Differences between the ensemble means of Actual and Counterfactual (A − C) (a, d, g, j), Future and Actual (F − A) (b, e, h, k) and Future and Counterfactual (F − C) (c, f, i, l) scenarios for PW and IVT (A − C), CAPE (d–f), time integrated mean vertical motion (g–i) and accumulated precipitation j–l. (b) PW, (d) IVT, (f) CAPE (h) mean vertical motion, (j) precipitation rate and (l) accumulated precipitation on the 23rd January 2020.Full size imageTo ensure that the differences between the scenarios are meaningful, a signal-to-noise analysis38 using the 5 member ensemble spread is conducted to test for significance (see Section Signal-to-noise analysis for definition). The black diagonal hatching in Fig. 3a–c indicates statistically significant differences between the scenario ensembles across the whole domain for PW. The box and whisker plots in Fig. 4 show the signal and noise distributions based on the corresponding spatially averaged time-series for each variable. The three ‘noise’ box plots on the left show differences between pairs of members within the same warming scenario ensemble, while the ‘signal’ box plots on the right show the differences between pairs from different scenarios (see Section Signal-to-noise analysis). For PW in Fig. 4b the spread in the noise distributions are small, all with median values roughly centred around 0 kg m−2. Meanwhile, the three right signal distributions are fully distinguishable from the noise ones with narrow inter-quartile ranges (IQR) and median differences around 1.5 kg m−2, as is clear from the well separated time-series in Fig. 4a.The white arrows in Fig. 3a, indicating ensemble mean IVT differences for C − A, show a marked increase in the cyclonic moisture convergence. The greatest IVT increases are seen over the Mediterranean as opposed to the coastal region of the Iberian peninsular where heavy precipitation occurred. As with PW, the increase in the IVT magnitude is not as strong in F − A (Fig. 3b) compared with A − C (Fig. 3a). Moreover, although in general the differences are positive, the strong cyclonic pattern is not as clear in F − A. The spatially averaged time-series in Fig. 4c show a 5.4 ± (0.4)% increase in IVT between F − A over the ES region, half that of the 10.8 ± (1.0/0.7) % increase recorded in A − C. The corresponding signal-to-noise analysis for IVT in Fig. 4d is similar to that of PW, with a small range in the IQR noise distributions indicating that the ensemble members do not show a large spread. Again a significant signal-to-noise ratio is visible, with the median of the signal distributions greater than the corresponding 75th percentile of the noise ones. These significant differences of PW and IVT between the warming scenarios are reflected in the spatial homogeneity of Fig. 3a–c.While deep convection was not the dominant driver of storm Gloria, we examine the changes in CAPE between the scenarios to understand the role of warming the available energy for convection. As with the PW and IVT, the evolution of CAPE in 3d, e also shows larger increase in A − C compared to F − A, with some statically significant decreases visible when moving from the Actual to the Future scenario. Here however the spatial structure is not homogenous, with significant changes in CAPE occurring predominately over the Mediterranean as opposed to over land. Unlike PW and IVT, the ensemble average time-series of CAPE over the ES region in 4(e) shows an almost threefold increase between A − C (52.2 ± (24.8/10.2) %) compared to F − A (18.5 ± (13.8/7.4) %), albeit with a larger ensemble spread. The time-series also show a series of sharp peaks in the three scenarios, with the largest occurring towards the end of the storm’s life cycle. Due to the spatial heterogeneity of CAPE and to the predominately 0 J kg −1 values before the 21st January 2020 the signal-to-noise ratio is not so strong in Fig. 4(f), with only the A − C and F − C distributions showing significant differences.Clausius-Clapeyron scalingFigure S7 shows the 2 m temperature time-series for all three warming scenarios (and the respective Past and Present ERA5 periods), averaged over the 30∘N - 60∘N, 50∘W - 10∘E domain. This region was chosen as it encompasses the sub-tropical northern Hemisphere region of interest, including the north Atlantic generation site of the storm. Looking at the average background temperature difference between the scenarios over this region, we find a temperature increase of 2.1 ∘C between C − A and a further 1.0 ∘C from F − A, based on all months in 2018-2024. Based on these background temperature changes, the average increases during storm Gloria in both PW and IVT, – shown in the top left corner of Fig. 4a, c – roughly follow what we would except from the Clausius-Clapeyron (CC) relationship of an increase of 6–7% K−1 in atmospheric moisture. In the case of IVT, the increase occurs due to increases in the specific humidity, which is directly impacted by the background thermodynamics. The nudged horizontal winds between 700 and 100 hPa (see Section Model Setup) prevent large changes in the dynamic component.Impact of a warming oceanFor PW and IVT in Fig. 3a–c, larger differences between the scenarios were observed over the ocean than over land. These larger values will partly be driven by increases in the sea surface temperature as we move through the warming scenarios, shown in Figure S8. Increases in sea surface temperatures drive increases in latent heat flux (evaporation), adding additional atmospheric moisture. In the case of IVT, this directly enhanced the available moisture for precipitation being driven into the coastal region. For CAPE, the changes observed in Fig. 3d–f are also predominantly offshore. Moreover, there is an almost threefold increase in CAPE from F − A to A − C when averaged over the ES domain, compared to the approximate twofold expected from the CC scaling alone. This greater increase may also arise from the enhanced latent heating over the ocean for A − C. This in turn increases the availability of warm, moist air at lower levels and provides additional buoyancy that promotes atmospheric instability39,40.Non-linear precipitation responseThe consistent thermodynamic changes between PW, IVT and CAPE across the warming scenarios would suggest a correspondingly larger precipitation response in the A − C comparison than in F − A, however this is not shown in the simulated precipitation. While the IVT timeseries acts as an excellent proxy for precipitation evolution, with a correlation of 0.89 between the two time-series in Fig. 3(c and k) (Actual scenario, ensemble mean), the systematic increases are not observed across the warming scenarios. Averaged over the ES region, the increase in accumulated precipitation is 2.8 ± (0.7/1.3)% for A − C and 3.4 ± (0.7)% for F − A (Fig. 4i). These increases indicate a strengthening of the precipitation under warming, however they do not follow the Clausius-Clapeyron scaling, highlighting the key role of dynamical modulation.To explore this non-linear response, in conjunction with precipitation we examine changes in vertical motion, a key dynamical control on precipitation. In the spectral nudging framework employed here, only the two-dimensional vorticity is constrained, while vertical motion is free to evolve (in line with the model’s physics) in response to the imposed large-scale flow and local thermodynamic conditions (Section Model Setup). The time-series of the instantaneous vertically averaged (400–900 hPa) vertical motion and precipitation (Fig. 4g, k) are not well defined between the warming scenarios. Consistent with this, the signal and noise distributions (Fig. 4h, l) indicate that changes in these flux variables are not statistically robust. Nevertheless, a weak reduction in mean vertical motion is apparent across the warming scenarios (−2.6 ± (−1.8/−1.6) % for A − C and −2.4 ± (−1.1/−2.1) % for F − A), which likely contributes to the muted precipitation increase in A − C despite larger thermodynamic enhancements.While instantaneous domain-mean signals are weak, Fig. 3g–l shows that stronger but highly localised changes are present in both accumulated precipitation and the temporal persistence of mean (vertically averaged 400 - 900 hPa) vertical motion. We analyse the temporally integrated mean vertical motion to characterise the net effect of sustained ascent and subsidence over the full duration of storm Gloria. Although much of the fine-scale structure in Fig. 3g–l reflects internal variability and storm-scale reorganization, the presence of statistically significant patches (shown by black diagonal hatching) where changes in time integrated mean vertical motion and precipitation co-locate, indicates dynamically meaningful responses. In particular, the A − C comparison exhibits significant increases in accumulated precipitation over northern Catalonia—one of the regions most severely affected during Storm Gloria—coincident with enhanced upward motion. In contrast, the F − A comparison shows significant precipitation increases displaced southward, toward the Valencia region, again aligned with localized increases in mean vertical motion. The correlation between the vertical motion and the accumulated precipitation is quantified in Figure S9 where blue stippling marks regions with a negative two-sided Spearman-rank correlation r < − 0.75 between these two fields (p < 0.05). The heavy concentration of blue stippling just east of the heaviest coastal impacts highlights the key role of vertical ascent in driving precipitation.Overall the responses in Fig. 3g–l should not be interpreted as providing a uniform climate change signal. Instead, they demonstrate how thermodynamic amplification interacts with storm dynamics to reorganize ascent and precipitation within a tightly constrained synoptic environment. Indeed, at these local scales, differences in accumulated precipitation reach values between −70 and 70 mm in both comparisons, underscoring the strongly non-linear and spatially heterogeneous nature of the response.Accumulated precipitationThe robust climate-change signal begins to emerge primarily at larger spatial scales and in integrated quantities, as shown by the accumulated precipitation in Fig. 4i, j. Unlike in the other box plots, the distributions in Fig. 4j represent the differences in accumulated precipitation between the various member pairs over the 23rd January2020 only.While the signal distributions for the precipitation rate in Fig. 4l are wide and greatly overlap with their corresponding noise distributions, the signal distributions in Fig. 4j are much narrower and are well separated from the internal ensemble spread. When examining the cumulative impacts, there is an overall increase of 6.3 ± (0.9/1.6)% in accumulated precipitation from the Counterfactual to the Future scenario. Figure 5 shows the accumulated precipitation for the three different scenarios (ensemble mean) over the storm. Here the black hatching shows the areas that received over 138 mm, a threshold determined by the 95th percentile of accumulated precipitation in the Counterfactual scenario over this period. This threshold is the 95th percentile of the Counterfactual scenario for this period in the ES region.Full size imageDiscussionThis study uses the novel ~ 9 km global storyline simulations from30 to investigate how record-breaking storm Gloria might have evolved in a cooler or warmer background environment. The large-scale dynamics of the storm were held close to the observed conditions using spectral nudging, allowing for the isolation of thermodynamic influences. This approach provides a physically grounded perspective on how anthropogenic warming may have modified the severity and spatial distribution of impacts during the devastating extreme event.A key step in this work was the evaluation of the seven-year DJF distributions of PW, IVT, CAPE, and precipitation. The intent of this analysis was not to detect climate change trends from the ERA5 7-year distributions – which would be infeasible over such short periods – but rather to demonstrate that the background warming between the Counterfactual and Actual scenario produced consistent and physically plausible shifts in the variable distributions. Across all thermodynamic variables, the warmer scenarios exhibited systematic rightward shifts in their distributions, reflecting the increased saturation vapour pressure (moistureholding capacity) of a warmer atmosphere. Given that the ERA5 Past and IFS-FESOM Counterfactual do not represent the same meteorological conditions (given the nudging in the Counterfactual), the close correspondence between the changes in the Counterfactual-Actual storyline distributions and those seen between ERA5 Past and Present gave confidence that the model’s response to warming is realistic and consistent with the observed warming recorded in the ERA5 reanalysis.Beyond validation, these multi-year distributions allowed us to contextualise the extremeness of Gloria within each warming scenario. This highlighted the potential for alternative attribution perspectives to be explored, such as percentile-based extremeness or probability-of-exceedance metrics, not seen in storyline analyses where data normally spans only the event in question. In the case of Storm Gloria, this analysis showed that the event consistently lies in the extreme tail of the precipitation distribution across all datasets considered, underscoring its exceptional character irrespective of resolution-dependent differences in precipitation. Moreover, the fact that precipitation totals for storm Gloria in the Actual distribution did not occur in the Counterfactual distribution, highlight—in line with41—that background warming drives an increase in the intensity of precipitation extremes.The thermodynamic response of the atmosphere during storm Gloria across the warming scenarios broadly followed expectations from Clausius-Clapeyron scaling. The increases in PW and IVT scaled approximately with the imposed background temperature changes, closely reflecting the increases in the atmospheric saturation vapour pressure. Temporally, IVT also served as an excellent proxy for precipitation evolution, consistent with42, who identified IVT as a dominant control on extreme precipitation over coastal regions in dynamically driven extra-tropical systems. However, while IVT effectively captured the temporal evolution of precipitation, it did not replicate the magnitude changes between warming scenarios.The ocean was found to play an important amplifying role in the response. Larger increases in PW, IVT and CAPE occurred over the Mediterranean sea than over land, consistent with warmer sea surface temperatures enhancing latent heat fluxes and lower-tropospheric moisture supply. This offshore thermodynamic enhancement helped precondition the atmosphere for precipitation over the coastal region. The disproportionate increase in CAPE – particularly in the Counterfactual-to-Actual comparison – further suggested that ocean-atmosphere coupling contributed additional buoyancy beyond what would be expected from moisture scaling alone. Yet, despite the larger temperature increases in A − C compared to F − A, the associated precipitation response did not scale proportionally, highlighting that local precipitation extremes in storm Gloria were not driven solely by thermodynamic potential but also by extreme dynamical conditions43. This divergence from CC scaling is consistent with previous studies44,45, which show that while daily mid-latitude precipitation tends to follow CC scaling, extreme sub-daily rainfall is often modulated by local dynamical processes and can deviate substantially from the canonical rate.Consistent with this interpretation, the precipitation response in the simulations was found to be highly localised and spatially heterogeneous. Instantaneous, domain-mean vertical motion and precipitation rates exhibited weak and statistically insignificant differences between warming scenarios. In contrast, time integrated mean vertical motion over the full storm duration revealed a weak overall decrease in ascent with spatially coherent patterns of sustained ascent and subsidence that closely aligned with accumulated precipitation anomalies. This persistent dynamic control, offset increased moisture availability and, as a result, the largest thermodynamic enhancement (A − C) did not produce the largest precipitation increase. Instead, a strongly non-linear and spatially heterogeneous precipitation response was observed. However, a known limitation of these simulations is the inconsistent initial conditions for the Future scenario compared to the Actual and Counterfactual, which could also partially account for why the precipitation increases in the Future case scaled differently than expected from the Actual-Counterfactual contrast.Storm Gloria exemplifies both the strengths and limitations of using the storyline approach implemented with spectral-nudging. On the one hand, its extreme impacts were tightly linked to a rare synoptic configuration involving a high-pressure blocking system, a cut-off low, and sustained moisture transport—features that are difficult to robustly simulate or attribute probabilistically in climate models. By constraining the large-scale dynamics, this framework allows a clean examination of how thermodynamic changes alone may have modified the event’s impacts. On the other hand, constraining the simulations with spectral nudging limits the extent to which dynamical feedbacks can adjust to warming. As shown by46, extra-tropical cyclones in warmer climates become more diabatically driven, with warming affecting both vertical motion and precipitation structure. In our framework such dynamical adjustments are suppressed by hourly nudging, meaning the atmospheric circulation was unable to adjust to the thermal and humidity changes induced by a warmer climate. Moreover, storm Gloria was highly dynamic in nature, with devastating impacts arising from high winds and extreme levels of IVT. The observed precipitation increases – lying below the CC scaling – highlight that it was the extreme synoptic situation and corresponding dynamics of the storm that mainly drove its intensity and the thermodynamics were not the only contributing factor. Further study should investigate how these dynamic storms would respond if the dynamics were allowed to evolve more freely, for example by relaxing the nudging frequency to every six hours. These sensitivity experiments could shift the balance between thermodynamic and dynamical contributions, potentially further amplifying the precipitation response.Overall, this study demonstrates that anthropogenic warming likely increased the severity and spatial extent of precipitation impacts during storm Gloria, but through mechanisms that are more subtle than simple moisture scaling. Thermodynamic amplification enhanced moisture availability and instability, while small, non-linear changes in the persistence and organisation of vertical motion determined where and how that moisture was converted into precipitation. Moreover, the global storyline simulations used here represent a versatile tool for impact-focused climate research that offers a powerful means of communicating the impacts of a warming climate through lived extreme events. The methodology complements probabilistic attribution approaches and provides information that is directly relevant for impact assessment and adaptation planning. As part of the Destination Earth initiative, such simulations offer a pathway toward more actionable climate information, particularly for regions like the Mediterranean where extreme events arise from complex interactions between thermodynamics, dynamics, and local topography.MethodsModel SetupThis study uses data from the spectrally-nudged storyline simulations performed with the coupled global climate model IFS-FESOM. The model combines the Integrated Forecasting System (IFS) for the atmosphere, land, and wave components, developed by ECMWF, with the Finite volumE Sea Ice-Ocean Model (FESOM2) developed by the Alfred Wegener Institute. The configuration used here corresponds to the ClimateDT setup based on IFS cycle 48r1 and FESOM version 2.531. The atmospheric component operates at a spectral resolution of TCo1279, corresponding to a horizontal grid spacing of approximately 9 km, and includes 137 vertical levels. The ocean component employs the unstructured NG5 mesh, whose horizontal resolution varies smoothly between 12 km in the tropics and 4.5 km in dynamically active regions and high latitudes, with 70 vertical levels.To constrain the model toward the observed large-scale atmospheric circulation, we employ spectral nudging following the approach of28. The method relaxes the model’s large-scale vorticity and divergence fields toward ERA5 reanalysis data32 at wavenumbers up to T60 and between 700 and 100 hPa. Additionally, a short e-folding time of 1 h is used, providing a balance between following the observed large-scale circulation and maintaining the model’s small-scale physics.Three distinct climate backgrounds are used to create the storyline simulations:
                  
                    Counterfactual (cooler) - representing a pre-industrial-like, cooler climate, based on 1950 boundary conditions and CMIP6-historical forcing;
                  
                  
                    Actual (present-day) - representing present-day conditions (2017–2024) under the SSP3-7.0 scenario;
                  
                  
                    Future (warmer) - representing a future climate approximately 2 K warmer than pre-industrial levels, based on 2040 initial conditions from nextGEMS31,47 projections under SSP3-7.0 forcing.
                  
                All experiments use the same observed large-scale circulation for the nudging but differ in their initial and boundary conditions, allowing us to assess how the same meteorological events evolve under different climate states. The Counterfactual and Actual simulations each include a five-year ocean spin-up (1945-1949 for Counterfactual and 2012–2016 for Actual) using stand-alone FESOM2 runs. Both Counterfactual and Historical use atmospheric initial conditions from ERA5 reanalysis (01/01/2017), whereas the Future experiment is branched from a nextGEMS47 coupled (ocean-atmosphere) run initialised in 2040. Minor inconsistencies in the spin-up length and initialisation strategy between the experiments may introduce small artefacts but are acceptable given the high computational cost and the focus on short-term atmospheric and surface responses rather than deep-ocean equilibrium. To mitigate further potential initialisation artefacts, especially the lack of initial atmospheric conditions for 1950 for the Counterfactual experiments, and following the same approach as in28, we incorporated an additional year of coupled model spin-up with nudging enabled to allow gradual adjustment of slowly evolving fields such as soil moisture, sea ice, and sea surface temperatures. As such, the simulations cover the period 2017–2024, however 2017 is excluded from the analysis as a spin-up year. Due to the nudging all scenarios cover the years 2018–2024 despite the different background climates (and hence temporal periods) they represent.The additional ensemble members are produced only for January 2020 due to computational constraints. Instead of directly perturbing the state variables (which is infeasible with the current model restart files), we use the lag-based approach48, where the spectral nudging is turned off for a varying number of days, e.g., member 1 nudging starts on day 1 of the month, member 2 nudging starts on day 2, etc. This provides an initial perturbation to each member, which stabilise over the following days. Sensitivity experiments showed that one week was sufficient for each member to reach its own equilibrium. Further technical details on the model configuration, nudging implementation, and experimental design are available in30.Calculation of IVTThe integrated vapour transport was calculated by$${\text{IVT}}=\frac{100}{g}\sqrt{{\left({\int }_{1000}^{300}q\,u\,dp\right)}^{2}+{\left({\int }_{1000}^{300}q\,v\,dp\right)}^{2}}$$
                    (1)
                where g is the gravitational constant of acceleration, q is the specific humidity, (u, v) are the zonal and meridional wind components and p is the pressure in hPa.Calculation of CAPECAPE was calculated using functions from MetPy49. Specifically we used the most_unstable_cape_cin function https://unidata.github.io/MetPy/latest/api/generated/metpy.calc.most_unstable_cape_cin.html, based on t, td (dew point temperature) and the parcel profile. The td and parcel profile were calculated using https://unidata.github.io/MetPy/latest/api/generated/metpy.calc.dewpoint_from_specific_humidity.htmland https://unidata.github.io/MetPy/latest/api/generated/metpy.calc.parcel_profile.html, respectively.Statistical testing for ERA5 comparisonFigure S2 shows two-tailed Pearson correlation coefficient between ERA5 and IFS-FESOM Actual scenario data for (c) MSLP, (d) PW and (g) IVT. These variables follow a normal distribution, determined by a Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for normality. For the precipitation in (h) the non-parametric Spearman’s rank correlation is used due to the heavily skewed extreme value distribution. The sample size n used for each correlation (each grid cell) is 144 (6 days of hourly data). An alpha level of 0.05 is used and any correlation with p > 0.05 is marked with green stippling. The structural similarity indexes (SSIM), between the hourly fields for ERA5 and Actual IFS-FESOM data are then shown for all variables in (a, b, e, f). The SSIM calculations use n = 6624 (72 latitude x 92 longitude for each hour). For both the correlations and the SSIM calculations the IFS-FESOM Actual data is interpolated to the lower resolution ERA5 grid.Taylor diagramsFigure S3 provides hourly time-series and Taylor diagrams comparing weather station data, the Actual simulations, ERA5 ( ~ 0.25∘ spatial resolution) and Multi-Source Weighted-Ensemble Precipitation (MSWEP) data ( ~ 0. 1∘ spatial resolution)37 for the ES region. The observational time-series (black) was created by averaging all the weather stations located inside the region. For the gridded data (ERA5, MSWEP and Actual) time-series, cubic interpolation was used to create point time-series from the gridded datasets to each weather station. These time-series were then averaged to create a mean for each region. The correlations on each Taylor diagram are the cross-correlations, computed using Numpy’s ‘corrcoef’ function.Fitting of probability distributionsWe analysed the statistical behaviour of three key atmospheric variables, precipitable water (PW), integrated vapour transport (IVT), and convective available potential energy (CAPE), using both ERA5 reanalysis and IFS-FESOM storyline simulations over the ES region. Since the storyline simulations (available for analysis) cover the period 2018–2024, two corresponding 7-year periods were selected from ERA5 for comparison: 1950–1956 (hereafter Past) and 2018–2024 (Present). All analyses were restricted to boreal winter (December-February, DJF). We acknowledge that the limited sample will impact the overall statistical robustness, however we are limited by the data available.To identify the most suitable theoretical distribution for each variable, we performed a one-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test50 to assess goodness-of-fit. For ERA5, the test was applied to 1000 random 7-year subsamples to account for sampling variability, whereas for IFS-FESOM it was applied to the Actual simulation. The candidate distributions included the Normal, Weibull, and Gamma families.The best-performing distribution for each variable was then fitted to the selected ERA5 (Past and Present) and IFS-FESOM (Counterfactual, Actual, and Future) datasets. To quantify uncertainty, two complementary resampling approaches were employed. First, a non-parametric bootstrap was used to estimate sampling uncertainty by refitting the distribution to multiple (1000 times) resampled datasets. Second, a parametric bootstrap was applied to assess the fitting uncertainty by generating synthetic samples from the fitted distribution and refitting them repeatedly (1000 times).All fits were performed using maximum likelihood estimation. For strictly positive variables (PW and IVT), the location parameter was fixed to zero to ensure physical consistency of the fitted distributions. For CAPE, which exhibits a highly skewed distribution, a logarithmic transformation was applied prior to fitting, and a Normal distribution was fitted to log(CAPE) without constraining the location parameter (see Table S2).Finally, to contextualise the fitted distributions in terms of extreme-event probability, we evaluated the likelihood of observing values as large as those recorded during Gloria. The daily maximum value during the event was extracted for each variable, and its probability was estimated from the fitted cumulative distribution functions (CDFs), along with uncertainty bounds derived from the sampling-uncertainty bootstrap.Signal-to-noise analysisTo validate the robustness of the differences between the scenarios we calculate a signal-to-noise analysis using the method outlined in ref. 38. Specifically, we test to see if the differences between pairs of different scenario ensemble members (signal) are outside the internal variability or noise of each ensemble (differences between pairs of the same scenario ensembles). The pairings for the signal and noise distributions can be expressed respectively as AmCn, FmAn, FmCn and CmCn, AmAn FmFn for m < n with m, n ∈ {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} for the 5 members. In the same way as38, we define a significant signal-to-noise ratio when the median of the differences between the inter-scenario pairs is greater (or less than if the median is negative) than the 75th (25th) percentile of the corresponding differences between pairs in the same scenario ensemble. To avoid incorrectly claiming significance for negligible accumulated precipitation and time-integrated mean vertical motion differences in Fig. 3, a minimum 2 mm and 2 Pa difference threshold was imposed respectively for the median of the inter-scenario differences.

Data Availability
              
              MSWEP reanalysis precipitation data can be accessed via \url {https://www.gloh2o.org/mswep/}. ERA5 reanalysis data is accessiblevia \url {https://www.ecmwf.int/en/forecasts/dataset/ecmwf-reanalysis-v5} Observational data from Meteocat (Catalonia) is availablehere \url {https://www.meteo.cat/observacions/xema}. Monthly and daily precipitation data from AEMET (all station data outside ofCatalonia) is available here \url {https://opendata.aemet.es/centrodedescargas/productosAEMET}. The hourly data used in this studyfrom AEMET was only available upon request. Data from the IFS-FESOM storyline runs are available through the DestinE DESPplatform \url {https://destine-data-lake-docs.data.destination-earth.eu/en/latest/introduction/introduction.html}.
